etymologies: mid 18th century: from Latin emot- ‘moved’, from the verb emovere (see emotion)

notes.text: The words emotive and emotional share similarities but are not interchangeable. Emotive is used to mean ‘arousing intense feeling,’ while emotional tends to mean ‘characterized by intense feeling.’ Thus an emotive issue is one likely to arouse people's passions, while an emotional response is one that is itself full of passion. In sentences such as we took our emotive farewells, emotive has been used where emotional is appropriate

definitions: arousing or able to arouse intense feeling

examples.text: animal experimentation is an emotive subject
the issue has proved highly emotive

shortDefinitions: arousing or able to arouse intense feeling

definitions: expressing a person's feelings rather than being neutrally or objectively descriptive

examples.text: the comparisons are emotive rather than analytic

shortDefinitions: expressing person's feelings rather than being neutrally descriptive
